text: Swiss hopes of defeating the Netherlands in the Davis Cup were severely hurt Friday when 15th-ranked Marc Rosset was rushed to hospital with an injured foot.
Rosset abandoned his match against Jacco Eltingh in the second set, while leading 6-4, 2-3. He twisted his foot while running for a forehand volley on his own service game.

Sobbing with pain and disappointment before the home crowd, Rosset limped off the court. He was taken to hospital for X-rays. It was not immediately clear if he would be able to play in the weekend matches.
'I'm not happy about winning in this manner,' Eltingh said. 'It's horrible for Rosset, especially as it happened in his home town.'
Switzerland's Jakob Hlasek was due to meet the Netherlands' Richard Krajicek later. The matches are the opening singles in the first-round world group tie.
Rosset and Hlasek, ranked 71st, normally team up for the doubles. The reserve members of the squad are Lorenzo Manta and Patrick Mohr, ranked only 238th and 302nd respectively.
'It hurts Switzerland because they have only two good players,' said Stanley Franker, the Dutch coach.
